mentions.context: SPAdes and GAT assembled all 33 instances, but SPAdes performed two #local misassemblies errors, while GAT is the only tool without any kind if misassemblies (cf.
Note that SPAdes uses an advanced abstraction of NGS data where the genome assembly is seen as the problem of reconstructing a string from a set of pairs of k -mers (also called k-bimers).
Moreover, SPAdes uses A-Bruijn graphs [20] where the operations are based on graph topology, coverage, and sequence lengths, but not on the sequences themselves.
Tools like KmerGenie aim to analyze the sequencing data and to estimate the "best" k -mer size [3].
• Using the QUality ASsessment Tool (QUAST) [9] for quality assessment, we demonstrate that our approach produces assemblies of higher quality than the above heuristics.
Based on this assumption, Minia computes the copy-count of each unitig as its abundance divided by the longest unitig's abundance, rounded to the nearest upper integer value.
The set of unitigs was generated with the Minia assembler [4], while the best k-mer size was chosen based on the tool KmerGenie [3].
SPAdes and GAT assembled all 33 instances, but SPAdes performed two #local misassemblies errors, while GAT is the only tool without any kind if misassemblies (cf.
This exception concerns the Atropa genome, where SPAdes obtains 3 contigs (versus 5 obtained by GAT).
The abundance of any k-mer is directly counted by Minia.
we have generated synthetic sequencing reads using ART simulator Illumina [11].
However, we observed that the N 50 value2 obtained by SPAdes for this instance is worser than the one given by GAT.

software-name.rawForm: AMPL (A Modeling Language for Mathematical Programming)
software-name.normalizedForm: AMPL (A Modeling Language for Mathematical Programming)

mentions.context: The optimization model has been implemented using the AMPL (A Modeling Language for Mathematical Programming) language and the Gurobi solver (version 7.0) [10].
We would like to thank Guillaume Rizk for adapting the Minia assembler [4] for the purpose of our algorithm and for his help in data generation.
In the experiments reported in the table below, we used KmerGenie in order to find the right k -mer length as a function of the read coverage value.
An estimation of the copy-count of each unitig is also returned by Minia following the strategy described next.
This section compares the results of the tool we have developed (denoted here by GAT: GenScale Assembly Tool) with state-of-the-art assembly tools: Spades [1], SSPACE [2], BESST [22].
Most previous work on scaffolding is heuristics based, e.g., SSPACE [2], GRASS [8], BESST [22] and SPAdes [1].
The computational results were obtained on a Laptop Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-6700HQ (2.6 GHz, 16 GB RAM) running Linux Mint.
• We tested this strategy on a set of 33 chloroplast genomes and compared the results with three recent assemblers (SPAdes [1], SSPACE [2] and BESST [22]).
The set of unitigs was generated with the Minia assembler [4], while the best k-mer size was chosen based on the tool KmerGenie [3].
The optimization model has been implemented using the AMPL (A Modeling Language for Mathematical Programming) language and the Gurobi solver (version 7.0) [10].
